guide.introduction:
Build instructions for the 'Baby Interface Device' (BID), an ultra-simple USB Human Interface Device for Tiny Humans. Built to allow my kid to interact with the computer without destroying my keyboards. The BID is a DIY USB HID (Human Interface Device) that acts as a keyboard to trigger a single keypress (space bar in this case). The concept is to create a very large button that is baby-friendly to allow an infant to interact with computer games and educational software.

The project can be assembled in less than an hour for around $35 or less and requires very little knowledge of electronics or coding.

Usage

The BID is ideal for use with certain online baby game sites such as: Kneebouncers - an awesome ad-free site supported by annual membership Fisher-Price Online - some of these games will work with this thing too. They're free and not too bad. Also this thing is very handy to play/pause media sites like Pandora and Youtube.

DISCLAIMER: Choking and Strangulation Hazard! This has a cable on it and small parts

They're free and not too bad. Also this thing is very handy to play/pause media sites like Pandora and Youtube.

DISCLAIMER: Choking and Strangulation Hazard! This has a cable on it and small parts

Relevant parts
  • tap light
  • rgb led
  • small round breadboard
  • Wire
  • 1/4W 560 ohm resistor
  • teensy microcontroller
  • mini usb cable
  • Adhesive tape, double-sided
Tools
  • Needle Nose Pliers
  • Phillips head screwdriver
  • Soldering Iron and rosin core solder.
  • Wire strippers

lines.text: Open taplight by removing 4 screws from bottom. Put screws aside in safe place for reassembly. Remove plastic body, dome, and carefully take out the cardboard membrane. This membrane is delicate and is needed to activate the switch.
lines.text_raw: Open taplight by removing 4 screws from bottom. Put screws aside in safe place for reassembly. Remove plastic body, dome, and carefully take out the cardboard membrane. This membrane is delicate and is needed to activate the switch.

lines.text: Strip internal wiring and lightbulb for taplight. You can also remove the battery leads etc. But be careful not to damage the switch since you will reuse that for the button push. Desolder the leads from the switch.
lines.text_raw: Strip internal wiring and lightbulb for taplight. You can also remove the battery leads etc. But be careful not to damage the switch since you will reuse that for the button push. Desolder the leads from the switch.

lines.text: Place your rgb led on your breadboard if you chose to use one, or you can use a small piece of thin cardboard. The base helps the led stay in place.
lines.text_raw: Place your rgb led on your breadboard if you chose to use one, or you can use a small piece of thin cardboard. The base helps the led stay in place.

lines.text: Solder each of the 3 colors' leads to the resistors.
lines.text_raw: Solder each of the 3 colors' leads to the resistors.

lines.text: Solder wires (4 inches or so. Set the led onto the base and check wires reach the teensy for good length) to the end of each resistor and the common lead
lines.text_raw: Solder wires (4 inches or so. Set the led onto the base and check wires reach the teensy for good length) to the end of each resistor and the common lead

lines.text: Solder the common lead wire to ground (common cathode) or vcc (common anode)
lines.text_raw: Solder the common lead wire to ground (common cathode) or vcc (common anode)

lines.text: Solder a wire from the center pin on the switch and one on the outside.
lines.text_raw: Solder a wire from the center pin on the switch and one on the outside.

lines.text: Solder the wire from outside of switch to pin 11 on teensy and the other to vcc.
